This is the best video game story I've ever had the privilege of experiencing, I didn't think it was possible to cram so much emotional depth into a video game. This is 100% my current benchmark for story-driven single player games, in both game mechanics and narrative.

Thanks a million Naughty Dog, I can't wait for your next masterpiece.

The Last of Us part 2 is a third person survival horror game, set five years after the events of the first game. Joel and Ellie are now living in Jackson, but when a group of soldiers attack the town, Ellie must follow them to Seattle, where she finds herself caught in the middle of a war between two factions.

I watched season 2 of the TV show a few months ago, which adapted the first half of this game. I thought it was much weaker than season 1 / the first game, but at least it prepared me for some of the game‚Äôs controversial story choices.

[h1]Gameplay (high quality)[/h1]

‚Ä¢	Survival horror gameplay is similar to the likes of Resident Evil, Dead Space, and Evil Within. Each individual enemy can be dangerous if you‚Äôre not careful, and some can even instakill you. Meanwhile, ammo and healing supplies are limited. Or at least, your carrying capacity is limited. You‚Äôll find loads of stuff lying around, but I had to leave so many supplies uncollected. (I wish I could craft a bigger bag).

‚Ä¢	The game has much more action than the TV show, with many lengthy combat encounters against several different types of infected, and soldiers from two different factions, which makes the world feel much more dangerous.

‚Ä¢	Available weapons include pistol, shotgun, rifle, crossbow, flamethrower, SMG, and craftable trip mines, molotovs and pipe bombs. You can also pick up various melee weapons which break after a few hits, but it never takes long to find another.

‚Ä¢	The player can use walls, parked cars, and long grass as cover to sneak up behind enemies and stealth kill them. You can also perform ranged stealth kills by crafting a silencer for the pistol, or using a bow which is naturally silent. 

‚Ä¢	In many scenes, you‚Äôll travel with an ally who will help you to fight, and can also perform stealth kills. Meanwhile, in some areas you can get soldiers and infected to attack each other.

‚Ä¢	The biggest difficulty during combat is being outnumbered and flanked by soldiers with guns. Most of the infected are easy to deal with once you‚Äôre comfortable with the stealth mechanics.

‚Ä¢	The city has some open areas to explore, with multiple paths to progress through, and ruined buildings where you can scavenge supplies such as ammo, crafting materials, weapon components to upgrade your guns at workbenches (stability, damage, zoom scope, magazine capacity, fire rate), and pills which can be spent to acquire various character skill upgrades.

‚Ä¢	The player has manual flashlight control at all times, allowing you to see properly at night or when underground. I appreciate this, because not every game gives you this ability.

[h1]Story (low quality)[/h1]

‚Ä¢	Story had potential to be interesting, featuring themes of family and revenge, but ultimately I think the writers made several mistakes with the structure and content which hurt its overall quality.

‚Ä¢	Voice acting is excellent from the whole cast, but especially for the main characters. Troy Baker as Joel, Ashley Johnson, whose performance makes Ellie much more likeable than Bella Ramsey, and Laura Bailey (who is amazing in so many other games I‚Äôve played) as Abby.

‚Ä¢	I‚Äôve never been a huge fan of non-linear stories that jump back and forth in the timeline, in any media (TV, film, games). This is a problem for TLOU2 with the second act of the story being a lengthy flashback from a different character‚Äôs perspective, which means that I didn‚Äôt care about certain characters, having already seen how their story ends during the first act.

‚Ä¢	Story lacks the presence of an important character who has a reduced role, with other characters not being interesting enough to fill the void.

‚Ä¢	Its the kind of story where you have to believe that your character will happily kill thirty random soldiers while achieving a mission objective, but then absolutely freak out with guilt about killing one specific person.

‚Ä¢	Ending features not one, but two massive anticlimaxes. Honestly, even without knowing any spoilers before playing, I did kind of expect the story to end that way, but it was still annoying to actually see it happen.

‚Ä¢	I was also quite confused by one specific cutscene towards the end. [spoiler]A character clearly gets shot in the head, but a couple of scenes later, they‚Äôre totally fine, and they provide information which sets up the final act of the story. I was already feeling like this second scene was wrong somehow, like the tone was too perfect, so as soon as this character walked in to the room I was like ‚Äúoh, this isn‚Äôt real. He‚Äôs dead, so this is a dream, and any minute now we‚Äôre going to wake up back to reality‚Äù. But then the story continued on long enough for me to start thinking ‚Äúwait, is this real? This doesn‚Äôt make sense‚Äù.[/spoiler] I was so confused that I had to pause the game and watch the first cutscene again on Youtube, to confirm that yes, I definitely saw what I thought I saw. Honestly, after this, I kinda lost interest in the last part of the story.

[h1]Technical (low quality)[/h1]

‚Ä¢	It took me 25 hours to complete the story.

‚Ä¢	Environmental graphics look great, as your journey takes you through ruined buildings overgrown with plants, underground tunnels covered in fungus, and large forests.

‚Ä¢	Controls are fully rebindable and feel great with mouse and keyboard.

‚Ä¢	The game was very unstable for me, as I experienced 8 crashes, with the only consolation being the fact that autosaves are very frequent, so I never lost more than a couple of minutes progress.

‚Ä¢	While I had a constant 60 FPS with most graphics settings on high (RTX 3080, i7-12700K, 32GB DDR4, 1440p), unfortunately I also experienced a significant amount of stuttering. Thankfully it didn‚Äôt seem to happen during combat, and I played long sections without any stuttering, but it was very noticeable while exploring some parts of the world.

‚Ä¢	Towards the end of my playthrough I started to wonder if the performance issues were related to how long I‚Äôd been playing, like some kind of memory leak. I mostly played in sessions of 2-3 hours, and I think its possible that the first 60-90 minutes of each session were fine, with performance getting worse after that, starting with stuttering and eventually leading to a crash. But I can‚Äôt say for certain if that theory is correct. Maybe specific areas of the map are just poorly optimised.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Despite some technical issues and a weak story, The Last of Us part 2 is worth playing for fans of survival horror games, because of its entertaining combat systems, but I would advise waiting for a big sale.

‚Äú10/10 Would Cry Again‚Äù

Hours played: 35 (and about 12 of those were spent staring into the void).

This game emotionally suplexed me, then hugged me afterward. I came for the action and stayed for the heartbreak, the guitar solos, and the emotional damage. Every stealth kill felt like therapy, every cutscene felt like a breakup.

The story punches you in the soul, the visuals make your GPU sweat, and the sound design had me checking over my shoulder IRL. By the end, I wasn‚Äôt sure if I‚Äôd beaten the game or if it had beaten me.

Would absolutely relive the trauma again. 10/10 ‚Äî highly recommend if you enjoy beautiful narrative in 4K. üëç

The Last of Us Part II is an emotional, beautifully crafted experience. The story hits hard, the characters feel real, and the gameplay is smooth and engaging. It‚Äôs one of those games that stays with you long after you finish it. An absolute must-play. Emotional, bold, and beautifully made definitely one of the most memorable gaming experiences I‚Äôve ever had.

I avoided The Last of Us II when it originally released on PlayStation due to the controversy that surrounded it, and I continued to avoid it when a Vice article detailing the games supposed problematic politics regarding real world conflicts further put me off. But having been such a big fan of the first game, I finally decided that if the game's narrative themes made me uncomfortable, it was okay because games are art, and art isn't always supposed to make us comfortable. It's supposed to tell us something about the human psyche and I wanted to experience this game at least once.

After finishing the game, The Last of Us II delivered. I feel like that Vice article was clutching at straws with some of its assertions, and while I understand some of the controversy that surrounded the game at launch, much of it was unwarranted or turned out to be outright untrue, and I wonder if some of those people actually played the game. This was truly a brilliantly told story and I'm glad I finally got to play this masterpiece. I now feel incredibly stupid for giving any of the outside noise credence and not playing it sooner.


[h3]Performance[/h3]
This was however an experience I still almost never got to have. After the game crashed twice within the first 2 hours, I strongly considered getting a refund, given Nixxes' reputation for awful PC ports, and how poorly the port of the first game performed. Against my better judgement I pushed on and, fortunately, the game only crashed one other time during my 47+ hour playthrough and the game performed ridiculously smooth. For the record, I played this on a 4080, Ryzen 9 5950x, with 64GB of RAM, so I can't comment on how it performs on different systems.

[h3]Story (MAJOR SPOILERS)[/h3]
The game does a great job of making you empathise with Ellie and hating Abby who is initially the game's antagonist. I was hesitant to continue playing the game when it transition to Abby's perspective, and I put down the game for a few days. But, when I jumped back in, to my surprise, the game did an equally great job of helping you to empathise with Abby to the point of almost hating even Ellie! You grow to love so many of the characters, some of whom die by the other's hand, and I sobbed like a baby all throughout the [spoiler]final showdown, not knowing who to root for. It was such a rollercoaster of emotions as I was yelling for Ellie "kill her!", but reeling as I came to the realisation that Abby might actually die as I held her head beneath the water. I felt everything Ellie felt in that moment.[/spoiler] The crying didn't stop until some time after the credits had finished rolling, which I sat through in its entirety as I processed what I had just experienced. 10/10

[h3]Grounded Mode[/h3]
This was tough to get through in the best and worst of ways. As a veteran of grounded mode who Platinumed the first game, I thought I was ready to jump straight into the deep end with this one. I was not. I'm not sure if it's that much harder than the first game, or if my age as a gamer is catching up to me, but Grounded can be extremely punishing and genuinely stressful at the best of times. Being too stubborn to turn down the difficulty, I had to take breaks that sometimes lasted weeks to avoid the stress of another session in Grounded Mode, but always found myself coming back. I had to constantly restart from the last checkpoint, as I would always be caught by the first or second enemy on any given encounter. This padded my playtime significantly, and checkpoints being unreliable, and seemingly random, was a cause for much frustration. All that being said, I wouldn't have played it any other way. This feels like the definitive way this game should be played as it adds so much tension to the experience. Conservation of resources is king and stealth is the only viable option. It's incredibly rewarding when you finally beat that boss using every last bit of your resources, or escape an encounter by the skin of your teeth.

[h3]Pacing[/h3]
One thing this game does great is how it breaks up the up the action and takes you away from the stressful encounters to give you a moment to catch your breath. This gives you a chance to get to know the characters more deeply and understand what motivates them during the action-packed combat/stealth sequences. These moments always gave me a sense of relief and often put a smile on my face, how even in the face of such adversity, these characters could still have a laugh. Though, even through some of these sequences I was on edge, oftentimes for no reason... I guess another thing this game does great is making you expect danger when you least expect it!

[h3]Audio[/h3]
They went full Hollywood on this one. You never go full Hollywood when it comes to audio. Balancing is neither speaker or headset friendly, with gunshots, explosions and music cranked up to the max, and dialogue turned down so low, it's barely a whisper. There are volume sliders in the settings, including a "dialogue" slider, but this only affects dialogue during gameplay. Dialogue in cutscenes is handled by a separate "cinematics" slider, but this is an all-encompassing slider that also handles the volume for gunshots, explosions and music in these cutscenes, so there's no way to rebalance cutscenes so dialogue is audible. Subtitles are a must unless you're happy to blow either your speakers or eardrums, or wake up the neighbours during your late night sessions. If not subtitles, at the very least thick walls.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
My verdict is that Naughty Dog doesn't miss. As the game is currently on sale, I can't recommend enough. Play the game, enjoy, and thank me later.

The Last of Us Part II Remastered takes an already divisive but undeniably ambitious game and gives it the treatment it always deserved. This isn‚Äôt a simple resolution bump; it feels like a definitive edition that respects both the original vision and the players who loved (or struggled with) that vision.

On PS5, the first thing that hits you is how clean everything feels. The higher resolution, smoother performance, and faster loading make replaying the story far more immersive. Seattle‚Äôs ruined streets, dense foliage, interiors choked with dust and decay ‚Äì it all feels sharper and more alive. The improved fidelity doesn‚Äôt just make the game prettier; it makes the violence, the quiet moments, and the environmental storytelling land harder.

The new No Return roguelike mode is a surprise highlight. What could have felt like a throwaway extra is actually dangerously addictive. Cycling through encounters, experimenting with different characters and builds, and getting dropped into tense combat sandboxes gives the already excellent gameplay a new, replayable structure. It leans into what Naughty Dog does best ‚Äì tight, high-stakes encounters ‚Äì but lets you enjoy them without the emotional weight of the full narrative every time.

The Lost Levels and behind-the-scenes content are a love letter to people who care about how games are actually made. Seeing unfinished spaces, playing through cut content, and listening to developer commentary turns the remaster into a mini interactive documentary. It doesn‚Äôt undercut the main story; it deepens your appreciation of why certain choices were made.

The guitar free play mode is another small but meaningful addition. It takes what was a cool in-game detail and turns it into a little creative sandbox. It‚Äôs the kind of feature that shows a studio paying attention to what players latched onto the first time around.

Story-wise, nothing fundamental has changed ‚Äì and that‚Äôs good. Part II is still bold, uncomfortable, sometimes exhausting‚Ä¶ and that is exactly why it works. It‚Äôs a game about consequences, cycles of violence, and the ways grief rots people from the inside. You don‚Äôt walk away ‚Äúhappy,‚Äù you walk away affected. In Remastered form, with the added modes and the technical polish, it‚Äôs easier than ever to appreciate the risk and craft behind it.

If you hated the story the first time, this version probably won‚Äôt change your mind. But if you were on the fence, curious, or already loved it, The Last of Us Part II Remastered is the best way to experience it: technically refined, feature-rich, and packed with smart extras that respect your time and your curiosity.

Verdict: A brutal, beautiful, fully realized version of one of the most daring games of the last decade. If you‚Äôre willing to be challenged emotionally, this remaster is absolutely worth your time.

[i]A disappointing love letter.[/i]

This isn‚Äôt a rage-fueled rant. Nor is it a holistically negative perspective of what was presented, or a staunch refusal to accept and embrace change. This was born out of a genuine admiration of the predecessor, and disappointment for what followed. 

I absolutely adored the first game, so my disappointment with the way the narrative was handled was immeasurable. Suffice it to say, this was not a worthy enough successor. Yet in spite of this, just because I‚Äôve elected a negative outlet for my perspective, it does not correlate to regret. Most people will still enjoy this entry, myself included. But, the message could have been so much more powerful had what I‚Äôm about to dissect been properly handled.

So everything is officially set in motion by one very particular plot point that I wager most already know, but I‚Äôm not in the business of criticising this point, nor its specifics. Anyone who was enraged by this decision was rightfully so, but not so much as to warrant dropping the game entirely; I understand the sentiment, but it‚Äôs a decision bred from raw emotion. Once everyone sits with the circumstances, the pain wanes, which is what the developers wanted.

They want you to feel as Ellie did, this decision was specifically designed with the intention to guide the player into what can only be described as pure, unfiltered rage, with a strong lust for revenge. The overarching theme of the story is to detail both the void revenge leaves, but also its inevitable emotional and physical trauma, as well as the importance of empathy. So with this in mind, it‚Äôs not off to a bad start; an abrupt, and considerably unwelcome one, but it sets itself up strongly nevertheless. 

However, whilst the game preaches the futility of revenge, it contradicts itself already: we see the successful, albeit sudden, brutal, but nevertheless complete nature of Abby‚Äôs revenge. We‚Äôre meant to empathise with Ellie at this point, to feel the same rage she feels, but are punished for it despite it being begotten out of the very same principle the story wishes to diminish through Ellie. Instead of trusting the player to reflect on difficult circumstances, the game insists on telling us exactly how we should feel, oftentimes through emotionally manipulative design; as opposed to inviting empathy, it demands it irrespective as to whether or not its foundation has been properly established. I didn‚Äôt need the game to lecture me on the importance of considering the plight of others, or the reality of the emptiness that characterises revenge's conclusion; they didn‚Äôt trust me to come to this conclusion myself. Instead, this message is spoon-fed with so much force that it undermines its own moral complexity. The core problem here is not the theme, but that the design philosophy presumes distrust in the ability for the players to empathise without being steered towards any particular conclusion.

Nevertheless, this blends nicely with the next point: certain characters are elevated disproportionately for the sake of idealism that undermines the narrative. Simultaneously, the characters we are naturally rooting for are diminished, not sentiments earned through well-written character development, but deliberately through narrative decisions that feel punitive given the players existing emotional investment in the characters. As an example, Abby (the ‚Äòantagonist‚Äô) is not a compassionate person, her compassion is forced as a convenient excuse to humanise her. She wasn‚Äôt originally written to be morally or ethically flawed, rather she represents a hypocritical and broken symbol as a consequence of poor narrative decisions; [i]the game was rigged from the start.[/i] 

Likewise, they immediately betrayed the initial intention of wanting the player to feel as Ellie did, through a time skip disclosed far later in the game; Ellie's been stewing for weeks as compared to our mere hours. Would it not have been far more effective had there been deeper transitions that allow for grief, guilt and most importantly, growth, to land more naturally? Crucial moments are often undermined by a lack of emotional runway. 

The story doesn‚Äôt shy away from revenge‚Äôs bleakness, it leans into it, often to a degree that feels emotionally numbing rather than meaningful. This relentless, monotonous tone undermines the emotional balance and resolution of the player. Rather than leave us with melancholy to reflect on, we resent, exhaustfully so, the circumstances that have reaped this feeling of punishment for simply caring. There is a very fine line between allowing these melancholic emotions to resonate, as opposed to outwardly scolding the player for their engagement, because it may differ from what they‚Äôre supposed to be feeling. The empty feeling many may feel after completing the game isn‚Äôt bred out of the bleak narrative, but rather the bleak design philosophy. They favoured crushing the player for feeling wrong, irrespective of a personal moral and ethical compass that already outmanoeuvres the game‚Äôs. There‚Äôs an important difference between tragic, and emotionally punitive, unfortunately veering into the latter category; we‚Äôre devastated not because of Ellie's tragedy, but because we‚Äôre punished for wanting her story and not Abby‚Äôs.

At any rate, the purpose of the story is clear from the beginning; they‚Äôre valid, and admirable to explore, but it‚Äôs approached with a crippling lack of subtlety, making it more of a lecture than an actual, tangible experience. The narrative is designed such that any interpretation is restricted other than what Naughty Dog wants you to feel as opposed to the emotional ambiguity that made the message of the first game so powerful. Consequently, you are forced to align with the developers conclusions over engaging with the narratives moral tension. They wanted to embody the whole notion of ‚Äúyou either die the hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain‚Äù, but without the subtlety or grace such a complicated narrative decision beckons for. The design philosophy isn‚Äôt exploring moral ambiguity, but rather precisely limiting your ability to interpret events independently; it doesn‚Äôt ask a question, it answers it, then punishes you for not agreeing fast enough.

It‚Äôs difficult to ignore the sensation that Naughty Dog is only forcing so many of these themes on the player, because many seemingly disregarded, or didn‚Äôt understand the weight of the first game's ending. This way, instead of an ‚Äòambiguous‚Äô decision that Joel made, they forced everyone to understand that decision, and are subsequently forcing everyone to understand the weight of the consequences in this game as opposed to allowing people to lose the point. Importantly, I am merely speculating, but irrespective of my speculation, this notion isn‚Äôt entirely unfounded, so whether or not there is some truth to it seems inevitable; it‚Äôs simply a matter of how much.

There‚Äôs a lot more to cover, but I feel as though I‚Äôve touched on the main reasons as to why The Last of Us: Part 2 crumbles. These flaws didn‚Äôt just dull the experience, they hollowed it. What could have been a meaningful, devastating story of loss and redemption instead became a suffocating lecture, distrustful of the very audience it tried to move. And as someone who adored the original, that‚Äôs what makes it all so hard to bear. I wasn‚Äôt just disappointed by the direction. I was left questioning whether the story I once loved had ever been understood by the very people who created it.

The Last of Us Part II is objectively a good game, no matter how you slice it. So why is it getting a thumbs down? Well, that's actually the main argument of this review.

The biggest shift that Part II did that made it so controversial, was the shift in tone. If Part I was dark enough for a lot of people, Part II broke barriers in what people thought was possible. But that's not my issue with it. It's the storytelling. It's something reminiscent of scrambled eggs. A mistake that at least the TV series is fixing.

The story is everywhere. It doesn't start at the beginning, it starts somewhere around the middle, then goes back to the past in flashbacks, then goes back and forth again and again. It's so convoluted, and I really can't see a reason why the writers set it up this way. Maybe they thought they were breaking barriers in storytelling - they weren't, in fact it was a mistake to write it this way, because it's simply not compatible with character driven narratives.

Part I in contrast, was a simple, linear, and deeply personal story about dealing with loss and moving past it. Part II, in turn was not even a story - it's just a cautionary tale about the dangers of revenge. The whole game plays like its trying to make a point, and that point is hammered again and again, almost to preaching levels. Part I wasn't trying to make any particular point about violence - it was simply understood by anyone playing, just by being in that world, that this is how things work now. And it does work, because it's simple. It's told through the characters eyes.

Part II, however tries to give you the perspective of two opposing sides, and that's the main flaw in my opinion. It's structured much like a dissertation. It's not about telling a story and making it into an emotional experience, it's about proving a point by examining the evidence. It's about making it as objective, and impersonal as possible.

But humans don't work that way. Part II dehumanizes the player in that regard, by making us hyper aware of what happens on both sides - a thing that is not possible for the characters. That just takes so much away in my opinion. The whole charm of Part I was developing this bias towards Ellie, which will make you as a player want to protect her no matter what by the end. This bias is what makes us human, and Joel was able to embody that perfectly. But here in Part II, it deconstructs any attachment you have with Ellie in favor of Abby, only to deconstruct it again and leave you with nothing, just to prove a point.

Part II was not supposed to be fun. It was supposed to be an experiment. It was too concerned with being revolutionary, that it forgot to be fun. It tried to break barriers in storytelling, and it ended up being a fiasco. Some people have commended the writers for taking risks with Part II, but players aren't looking for anything revolutionary, they just want to have a good time. That being said, Part I was pretty groundbreaking for a game that "played safe".

The only redeemable aspect of Part II was it's technical achievements. The game is unbelievably gorgeous, unfathomably realistic in it's depictions of everything, specially violence, and a complete leap beyond everything that was achieved with Part I. It just plays amazing. The combat, the exploration, the crafting, the stealth, the visuals, the motion capture, the voice acting, the soundtrack... it is simply a masterclass in every technical aspect.

However, unfortunately, that only serves to further exacerbate all the problems with the narrative. While its carcass shines in utter brilliance, it's rotten core is exposed and left to burn in the sun.

Went into this almost completely blind after recently finishing part I. 
I'll try keep it spoiler free, but there may be a few minor ones.
Lets start with the positives:
- Gameplay is definitely enhanced since part 1. It's still simple, but well executed. Newer game and newer mechanics. The gameplay is enjoyable.
- It looks good. This game is very pretty and captures the atmosphere of a post apocalyptic environment very well.
- Weapon upgrades and customisation is pretty neat

The negative: 
- The story is a scrambled mess. Taking place several years after the first game, you spend the first half of the game playing Ellie, who in this game has the personality of a cardboard box with little to no actual character development. She's one dimensional and boring, she doesn't have many friends. Her reason for rampage seems more like an excuse to vent than anything else. She makes bad decision after bad decision as you control her. 
The second half sees you playing as Abby. Abbys story is actually pretty well done considering. Although we may not agree with everything she has done, through her eyes we see that she does regret her actions and she has a somewhat decent arc. However, her story should be an option, and we shouldn't be forced to play as her for 10-12 hours. 
- The significant event that occurs a couple of hours in is stupid. I don't care that they did it or that it happened, but how it happened is bad. Even if the character had "grown soft", it's still a post apocalyptic wasteland. Even a "soft" person isn't going to trust a random small group armed militia - especially after having  lived a similar life in the past. 
- The game is too long. Long games are fine, but this dragged. As the stories converge between Abby and Ellie, we expect a big climax, but there wasn't one - then the game continues for another couple of hours, but there is no climax, and we are given no time to process the events that occurred. As as previously mentioned, when we do get back there, it falls flat anyway. 
- Ellie demonises Joel for taking her from the Fireflies hospital - she despises him because it wasn't his decision to make. However, the great moral quandary at the end of the first game is totally glossed over - there's barely any mention of the fact that the Fireflies were doing the exact same thing. They did Joel dirty by completely glossing over this. 

If you're expecting a deep story driven game, this isn't it. Such a disappointment after how well the story in the first game was executed.
I was left with an utter sense of bewilderment by the end - having felt like I wasted my time and money on an unpolished story with no real substance. If I could, I'd get my money back.

Edit: To the people who think "I didn't get it" - I did. I understood the story and the developers intent, and it still sucks. Playing this game is probably my biggest gaming related regret.
